pull_request.title: Simplify column headers
pull_request.body:
I do not have the context to understand why it is done this way (it dates back to 2017), but I am not sure we still need two `<ColumnHeader>` components.

We can simplify the code this way, and the columns that were using `<ColumnBackButtonSlim>` have their title properly displayed now, it was hidden before.

The last commit adds a test harness to provide Intl / Router / identity contexts

issue.title: Fix bug where remote suspension causes local instance to remove remote follows
issue.body:
This does not have an issue number, but I noticed this bug while looking at the comment.

The comment presumes that this code will only be run when the suspension comes locally, but I've observed the code being triggered when a remote account gets suspended remotely, causing the local server to issue follow rejects to that account.

According to the comment, this is not intended, and any (temporary) local suspension will effectively remove remote follows.

comment.body:
The bug happens like follows;
- Alice@Amazing.com follows Bart@Beautiful.net
- Server A suspends Alice@Amazing.com
- Server A distributes this suspension via account update, triggering [this code](https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/blob/6ad203337496ed8c74ac6eaa3f4a9943afd3c50a/app/services/suspend_account_service.rb#L43)
- Server B gets account update, triggering [this service](https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/blob/cf6f70799b128d385d830d1f55eae8046bea3c60/app/services/activitypub/process_account_service.rb#L3)
- The Service [sets suspension](https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/blob/cf6f70799b128d385d830d1f55eae8046bea3c60/app/services/activitypub/process_account_service.rb#L146) to remote, and then [proceeds](https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/blob/cf6f70799b128d385d830d1f55eae8046bea3c60/app/services/activitypub/process_account_service.rb#L55) to [process the suspension change](https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/blob/cf6f70799b128d385d830d1f55eae8046bea3c60/app/services/activitypub/process_account_service.rb#L168)
- It enters `SuspensionWorker`, which calls `SuspendAccountService`, which calls `reject_remote_follows!`, which was supposed to only run under the assumption of local suspensions.

Ergo, suspending a local account gets remote servers to send `Reject` activities to that account's follows.

issue.title: Add administrative webhooks
issue.body:
Webhooks would benefit automation through the moderation API by notifying applications about system events in real-time. They would also enable integrations with chat apps like Discord, IRC and Slack, helping moderator coordination.

Events currently supported:

- `report.created`
- `account.created`

The `X-Hub-Signature` header adopted from the WebSub spec can be optionally used to verify that the payloads are authentic.

The payload delivered to the webhook has the form of:

```js
{
  "event": "report.created",
  "created_at": "2022-06-08T12:28:31.000Z",
  "object": {
    // The report entity would be here
  }
}
```

Mind that `created_at` at the top-level refers to the event itself, and not the `object`.

___

![Screenshot 2022-06-08 at 00-38-37 New webhook - Mastodon (Dev)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/184731/172494921-58f57aad-a653-484a-bbeb-d0549555595b.png)
![Screenshot 2022-06-08 at 00-38-51 Webhooks - Mastodon (Dev)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/184731/172494933-b3792416-6c86-4135-a2a6-dc5ed41925da.png)
![Screenshot 2022-06-08 at 00-39-05 Webhooks - Mastodon (Dev)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/184731/172494943-39c262ee-9c04-4022-afbf-cceaf9d5e5ba.png)


___

This project was funded through the [NGI0 Discovery](https://nlnet.nl/discovery) Fund, a fund established by [NLnet](https://nlnet.nl/) with financial support from the European Commission's [Next Generation Internet](https://ngi.eu/) programme, under the aegis of DG Communications Networks, Content and Technology under grant agreement No 825322.

comment.body: `report.updated` is triggered when the report itself is modified, but not when moderation notes are left on it. There is currently no webhook event for that.

issue.title: Delete migrations created prior to version 3.0
issue.body:
Opening this based on discussion in chat and in https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/24270#issue-1640971599

For first pass, I'm only deleting the old migrations. Will watch CI failures to see what scripts/checks need update as well and push more after that.

Will rebase against main after https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/27513 is merged and regenerate the rubocop todo to remove old migrations from that as well.

comment.body:
> Removed the CI workflows which were testing data migrations specific to the version 2.x series of migrations/data.

I strongly disagree with that, but I feel like I may not have given enough background into these tests.

They test both that the migrations run at all, and that the data migrations work as expected. We had cases of both breaking in the past, sometimes due to the migrations being plain wrong, sometimes due to `strong_migration` updates or updates to the Mastodon code, which the migrations have an over-reliance on.

Those things are definitely still worth checking.

As for the `populate_v*` tasks, they were written in this way for a mix of targetting explicit migrations, and limiting the number of `populate_v*` tasks, meaning test data is generally not populated right before migration involving them are run, but potentially much earlier. For instance, the `settings` stuff populated in the 2.4.3 task is mostly relevant for a 4.2 migration.

Therefore, I think the tests should be kept, and the `populate_v*` tasks lifted to a `populate_v3_0` task.

pull_request.title: Fix bug where remote suspension causes local to remote remote follows
pull_request.body:
This does not have an issue number, but I noticed this bug while looking at the comment.

The comment presumes that this code will only be run when the suspension comes locally, but I've observed the code being triggered when a remote account gets suspended remotely, causing the local server to issue follow rejects to that account.

According to the comment, this is not intended, and any (temporary) local suspension will effectively remove remote follows.

issue.title: Allow login through OpenID
issue.body:
OpenID is a decentralized authentication system. It allows to delegate the authentication to a third party trusted by the end-user. The last version (OpenID Connect) works over OAuth 2.0. It's alrady used by a lot of websites, but usually limited to a few big providers like Google or Facebook (don't ask why...).

Allowing to login on Mastodon through OpenID would also prevent to have to remember another login/password.


*For reference, @Sylvhem has submitted a request to add an OpenID provider in Mastodon: #4800.*

comment.body:
Had you considered using OpenID-2.0 too or would that belong to a different ticket ? I mention because OpenID-2.0 is already federated and providers are here already and different services already allow logging in via OpenID-2.0, for example:

 - https://www.openstreetmap.org/login
 - https://gitea.com/user/login/openid

issue.title: Update `UserMailer` to use paramaterization

labels.name: ruby
labels.description: Pull requests that update Ruby code

issue.body:
Similar to previous PRs for `NotificationMailer` and `AdminMailer`.

Summary:

- Adds missing spec coverage for the welcome and backup_ready mailers
- Add before_action for setting common instance vars
- Add default `to` value
- Add parameterization to almost all mailers (did not do the devise-descended ones in this PR)
- Use `default_i18n_subject` where it works, or a custom devise version where it doesn't (the built-in one does not pick up the right i18n scope from parent classes. Might revisit this in future PR).
- Fix one bug (I think!?) where the appeal_rejected mailer was not actually being sent

issue.title: Stuck Follow Request when following a WordPress Profile

labels.name: status/to triage
labels.description: This issue needs to be triaged

issue.body:
### Steps to reproduce the problem

1. Go to for example mastodon.art
2. Search for `pfefferle@notiz.blog`
3. Press "Follow" button



### Expected behaviour

Mastodon user follows WordPress User

### Actual behaviour

Process seem to be stuck ("Cancel follow")

### Detailed description

We have received some reports (here is the [ticket](https://github.com/Automattic/wordpress-activitypub/issues/523) on the WordPress plugin repo) that the Follow process seems to be stuck and not accepted by the WordPress instance.

Debugging on the WordPress site shows that when searching for the WordPress profile, all required endpoints (WebFinger, Followers, ...) are requested and the profile is displayed correctly in the Mastodon UI. However, after clicking the follow button, WordPress does not receive a follow request (or any other requests to the inbox), this also applies to a unfollow/re-follow. Sending an `accept` by hand, on the other hand, seems to work.

Another way to reset the follow process seems to be an @-reply. After sending an @-reply to the Mastodon profile,an unfollow/re-follow also seems to work.

An example profile: @pfefferle@notiz.blog
An example group: @notiz.blog@notiz.blog

For a few weeks now, the Mastodon UI has also been displaying a 500 error in the UI when requesting the internal featured-tags endpoint: https://mastodon.social/api/v1/accounts/[...]/featured_tags.

Here is an example endpoint for the Featured Tags endpoint of WordPress: https://notiz.blog/wp-api/activitypub/1.0/users/0/collections/tags

### Mastodon instance

mastodon.art, mastodon.ie, twit.social

### Mastodon version

v4.2.1

### Technical details

_No response_

comment.body:
I've created #27586, which is intended to help with one half of this problem; the fact that federation is wedged because of this issue, and isn't easily able to be unwedged.

The other half of this problem is for @pfefferle to fix on wordpress' side, where AF can be properly processed.

After this, and after an update, wordpress.com-hosted blogs can be properly accessed once more (after users cancel and refollow blogs they tried to follow).

pull_request.title: Have `Follow` activities bypass availability
pull_request.body:
This fixes https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/27458, and is related to (but does not resolve) https://github.com/Automattic/wordpress-activitypub/issues/523

This is in accordance with the suggestion I made here: https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/27525#issuecomment-1779880830

The consequences of this is that Follow requests can bounce around the queue for a while, without being affected by availability. They'll still be affected by stoplight, but those are temporary.

---

This PR is intended to help "wedged" federation, where a remote account is not "accessible" (or "stuck in Follow Request state") because the local server has stopped delivery for that server.

This is especially notable in cases where the remote server is a follow-along-like actor (such as a blog) which is not intended to have social dynamics, such as "following back", or "mentioning" the account out of the blue, which would've otherwise unwedged federation in other cases.

This PR adds a simple availability bypass to the delivery worker, which is only granted on the case of a user-initiated follow request.

These follow requests are then often accompanied by an authorisation, which then unwedges the delivery failure tracker, as it has now "seen" a response from that inbox. Normal federation can resume hereafter.

By effect, a `Follow` activity then becomes a SYN-like first step to re-establish federation after it has broken down or bugged via the availability tracker.

issue.title: Setting to opt out of quote posts or quote boosts
issue.body:
### Pitch

### The aim of this issue is to define 

1. A universal post attribute that communicates if the author of a post *wants* their post to be quote-posted or not, and
2. Any UI elements required for the user to control that post attribute.

### Implementation

1. Add a setting to `/settings/preferences/other` to "Allow your posts to be quoted by default." This setting would be off by default.
2. Add an attribute to posts to define whether they're quotable or not. *I'm not a dev but I imagine something like add a boolean (true/false) field `quotes`.*
3. Add a toggle to the post composer UI, so users can turn quoting on/off per post.
4. Both the toggle in settings and the per-post controls could have more fine-grained controls over who can quote post, e.g. followers only, local only, etc (this would mean the post attribute wouldn't be boolean).

### Motivation

Quote posting is already here on the Fediverse and Mastodon. Calckey has it, various apps have it. Technically speaking there's no way to stop quote posting. However if there is a per-post attribute that signals the post author's desires about quote posting for that post, then if servers or clients don't respect that attribute they can be defederated and/or avoided.

Since quote posting is already is already here, I'd like to see this post attribute added already and not wait until quote posting is built into Mastodon natively.

This issue is NOT for the implementation of quote post features. There are already a bazillion issues for that: https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/309, https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/14597, https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/15524, https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/19889, https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/22793 are the ones I know of. 

This issue has nothing to do with https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/22918, they're completely different features (URL sharing is not quote posting).

I looked for a duplicate issue but can't find one - only discussions about this in issues for implementation of quote posts.

comment.body:
Sorry, but I can't understand what the issue is with this function. It seems to me that Mastodon already has all the necessary tools to interpret the author's intent to allow 'quote boosts' in the post privacy settings: if a post is public, the author, in my opinion, exposes it to the possibility of being shared, reposted, and thus commented on. Mastodon already sends notifications for boosts; extending these notifications to 'quote boosts,' which, as I understand, are posts containing a URL to another post, should suffice. I also believe that the risk of 'quote boosts' being used maliciously is significantly reduced in an environment like Mastodon. Instance administrators, when establishing their rules, can clearly state how they want 'quote boosts' to be used. If they find a user violating these rules, they can take appropriate actions, just as they would with other non-compliant or unacceptable content according to the instance's guidelines. 
In conclusion - and I say this with all the love and respect I have for Eugen, the development team, and the project - I believe the problem is overestimated, and further delaying the implementation of this function could hinder the migration of news outlets and many users who are currently seeking an alternative to X, impeding the adoption of Mastodon. It would be a significant loss and a missed opportunity for Mastodon, user freedom, and the entire fediverse.
